content: Transform this into a web-based USMLE Step 1 study companion called AorteQ with these essential baseline features:  Authentication System: A. Welcome/Login Page:  Clean centered layout with AorteQ logo at top  "Login with your Aorteq account " header text Email input field with validation Password input field with show/hide toggle  "Forgot Password? " link (light purple, right-aligned) Primary  "Login " button (filled purple) Divider with  "Or " text  "Sign in with Google " button (white with Google logo)  "Sign in with Apple " button (black with Apple logo)  "Don't have account? Create an Account " text link at bottom All form fields should have proper validation and error states   Initial Study Plan Setup: A. Three-Step Wizard Interface:  Progress indicator at top showing 3 steps Back and Continue buttons at bottom Each step on its own page with slide transitions  Step 1: Exam Selection & Date   "Let's tailor things to your study plan " header USMLE Step 1 selector dropdown Calendar date picker for exam date Info text explaining time calculation  Step 2: Topic Selection  Multi-select grid layout showing:  Basic Sciences section:  Behavioral Science Pharmacy Biochemist Lab Epidemiology Lab Microbiology Lab   Organ Systems section:  Cardio Clinic Endocrine Clinic MSK Clinic Neuro Clinic Respiratory Clinic     Checkboxes for each topic Search/filter option for topics  Step 3: Study Schedule  Hours per day input (default: 3hr 30min) Weekly schedule selector  7-day grid showing M-Su Ability to select study days Visual indication of selected days   Automatic calculation of study plan duration Warning if schedule needs adjustment   Question Bank (QBank) Interface: A. Question View:  Progress bar at top showing position (e.g.  "Question 10/15 ") Question number and text in main area Medical case presentation format Image display area when applicable (right side) Answer options (A-E) in vertical layout Each option clearly separated Hover and selected states for options  "Eliminate Answer " toggle button Previous/Next navigation buttons Timer display (optional)  B. Session Analysis Dashboard:  Large circular progress chart showing session score Key metrics displayed prominently:  Questions completed (e.g.  "45/50 ") Accuracy percentage (70%) Average time per question (1m 30s) Total session time (0h 32m)   Performance breakdown by system/topic Bar charts showing strength/weakness areas Detailed question list with:  Correct/incorrect indicators Time spent per question Topic categorization     Progress Tracking Dashboard: A. Main Overview:  User's name and exam countdown timer Large circular progress indicator showing overall completion Weekly progress bar chart Study streak counter with visual indicators Score prediction meter showing:  Current predicted score (e.g.  "221 ") Passing score line (196) Target score line (240+)   Recent assessment scores:  Test name (e.g.  "NBME 25 ") Score achieved Date taken Trend indicators   Weekly subject breakdown Performance metrics for each topic    All features should follow these technical requirements:  Responsive web design (minimum supported width: 1024px) Clean, medical-professional aesthetic Primary color: #6366F1 (purple) Consistent spacing system Clear typography hierarchy Loading states for all async operations Error handling with user feedback Session persistence Real-time progress saving Browser compatibility: Latest Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge  This baseline version focuses on the core study experience while maintaining a professional and user-friendly interface that can be expanded with additional features in future iterations.

content.overview: Transform the existing Flutter app into a web-based USMLE Step 1 study companion called AorteQ, incorporating an authentication system, study plan setup, question bank interface, and progress tracking dashboard while maintaining a professional aesthetic and responsive design.
new_features: Three-Step Wizard Interface for Initial Study Plan Setup
modified_features: HomeView and HomeViewModel to accommodate new features
AppView to integrate authentication and study plan setup
UI components for responsive design and new aesthetic
content.architectural_changes: The project structure will be modified to include new folders for authentication, repositories, and new features. The state management will be adjusted to accommodate the new ViewModels and Repositories, ensuring that all data interactions are handled through the repository layer.
cross_cutting_concerns: Implement a testing strategy for new features and repositories
Update documentation to reflect new features and architectural changes
Ensure performance impacts are assessed, especially for data fetching and UI rendering
Address security considerations for user authentication and data handling
Implement data integrity checks for user inputs and progress tracking

content:
### Summary of Changes

This summary outlines significant modifications to the architecture, dependencies, and components of the application, focusing on the transition to a more structured and feature-rich design. 

---

#### 1. Additions (➕)

- **New Components:**
  - **Authentication Features:**
    - `login_view.dart`, `login_viewmodel.dart`, and `auth_repository.dart` added to handle user authentication.
  - **Study Plan Features:**
    - `study_plan_view.dart`, `study_plan_viewmodel.dart`, and `study_plan_repository.dart` introduced for managing study plans.
  - **Progress Tracking:**
    - `progress_dashboard_view.dart` and `progress_dashboard_viewmodel.dart` added for tracking user progress.
  - **Question Bank:**
    - `question_view.dart`, `question_viewmodel.dart`, and `question_repository.dart` added for managing questions.

- **New Methods:**
  - `login`, `signInWithGoogle`, and `signInWithApple` methods in the `LoginViewModel`.
  - `setExamDate`, `selectTopics`, and `generateStudySchedule` methods in the `StudyPlanViewModel`.
  - `loadQuestions` and `selectAnswer` methods in the `QuestionViewModel`.
  - `fetchQuestions` method in the `QuestionRepository`.

- **New Dependencies:**
  - Added `cloud_firestore` for data storage.
  - Updated `firebase_auth` for user authentication.

---

#### 2. Removals (➖)

- **Removed Components:**
  - The `home_view.dart` and `home_viewmodel.dart` have been eliminated in favor of the new authentication and study plan structures.
  - The `startup_view.dart` and `startup_viewmodel.dart` have been removed as their functionality has been integrated into the new login and study plan features.

- **Removed Dependencies:**
  - The `gap` package is still present but is no longer the primary focus for layout management.
  - Several dependencies related to the old structure have been removed from `main.dart`.

---

#### 3. Changes (🔄)

- **Architectural Modifications:**
  - The application now follows a more modular structure with dedicated folders for authentication, study plan, progress tracking, and question bank features.
  - The main entry point now initializes the `LoginView` instead of the `StartupView`, reflecting a shift to user authentication as the first step.

- **Modified Interfaces:**
  - The `AppView` now shows the `LoginView` first, and upon successful login, it navigates to the `StudyPlanView`.
  - Updated class diagrams and descriptions to reflect the new architecture and functionalities.

- **Dependency Version Changes:**
  - `firebase_auth` updated from `^2.0.0` to `^3.3.0`.
  - New dependency `cloud_firestore` added at version `^3.1.0`.

- **Behavioral Changes:**
  - The navigation flow has been altered to prioritize user authentication before accessing study plans and questions.
  - State management now utilizes new ViewModels for each feature, improving separation of concerns.

---

### Key Impacts

- **Breaking Changes:**
  - The removal of the `home_view` and `startup_view` means that any existing references to these components will break. Developers must update their code to use the new authentication and study plan features.
  - Changes in method names and signatures in the ViewModels may require updates in the calling code.

- **Required Updates:**
  - Update any references to removed components in the application.
  - Ensure that the new dependencies are included in the project configuration.
  - Review and adapt to the new navigation flow and state management practices.

---

### Conclusion

These changes represent a significant evolution in the application's architecture, focusing on user authentication and study management. Developers should prioritize updating their implementations to align with the new structure and take advantage of the enhanced features.
